description: Apparently from a Middle Dutch noun related to stuiven and cognate to German Staub (“dust”).

entries.meaning: The floating dust in a flour mill caused by the operation of grinding.
examples: The removal of the heated air, steam, stive, and flour from the millstones, is a proposition which does not appear to be more than sufficiently well understood.

verbs.description: stive (third-person singular simple present stives, present participle stiving, simple past and past participle stived)

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect, transitive, intransitive) To stew; to be stifled or suffocated.
examples: Let your cucumbers be ſmall, freſh gathered, and free from ſpots; then make a pickle of ſalt and water, ſtrong enough to bear an egg; boil the pickle and ſkim it well, and then pour it upon your cucumbers, and ſtive them down for twenty four hours; […] .

description: Related to Italian stivàre, Portuguese estivar.

verbs.description: stive (third-person singular simple present stives, present participle stiving, simple past and past participle stived)

entries.meaning: (transitive, sometimes with "up") To compress, to cram.
examples: His chamber being commonly stived with friends or suitors of one kind or other.
